name: Computer Science I
description: Basic concepts of programming and programming languages. Structured programming, stepwise refinement, and object-oriented development.

name: Computer Science I Lab
description: Required laboratory for CS 1180

name: Computer Science II
description: Advanced concepts of computer programming. Use of data structures and tools that facilitate programming.

name: Computer Science II Lab
description: Required laboratory for CS 1181

name: OS Concepts and Usage
description: Provides introduction to Linux and Windows operating systems and system administration. Covers files and directories, ownership and sharing, programs and processes, system calls, libraries, dynamic linking, command line shells, scripting, regular expressions and secure network protocols.

name: OS Concepts and Usage Lab
description: Required laboratory for CEG 2350

name: Computer Organization
description: Organization and sequential operation of digital computers. Binary and hexadecimal number systems, 2's complement arithmetic, program control, memory organization and hierarchy, addressing modes, stacks and parameter passing, interrupts and traps, I/O devices, DMA, cache, and virtual memory.

name: Computer Organization Lab
description: Required laboratory for CEG 3310

name: Discrete Structures and Their Algorithms
description: Discrete structures and their algorithms for  science. Emphasis on   and formal argumentation.

name: Discrete Structures and Their Algorithms Recitation
description: Required rescitation for CS 2200.

name: Technology and Society
description: Examines and evaluates the consequences of technology on individuals, organizations and society to recognize its benefits, potential, and limitations. Explores current social, ethical, legal and philosophical topics to understand how the Digital Revolution impacts society.

name: Data Structures and Algorithms
description: Study of the implementation of data structures and control structures in professional computer programs. Introduction to the fundamentals of complexity and analysis. Study of common standard problems and solutions (e.g., transitive closure and critical path). Emphasis on high-level language software design.

name: Logic for Computer Scientists
description: Fundamental material in foundations of logic most relevant to Computer Science. Propositional logic, predicate logic, modeling of knowledge, and algorithms for logical reasoning.

name: Comparative Languages
description: Fundamental concepts and paradigms underlying modern programming languages to enable better appreciation, comparison and evaluation of languages. Covers an object-oriented language, a functional language, a logic language, and a multi-paradigm scripting language. Basics of interpreters and compilers are explored through programming assignments.

name: Introduction to Software Engineering
description: Introduction to the concepts of Software Engineering. Software qualities, development life-cycle models, requirements analysis, semi-formal and formal systems modeling, system design, testing, and project management techniques. Case studies and a course project serve as examples illustrating the software engineering process.

name: OS Internals and Design
description: Overview of operating systems internals. File-system usage and design, process usage and control, virtual memory, multi user systems, access control. Course projects use C++ language.

name: Calculus I
description: Examines limits, the derivative, differentiation, applications of the derivative, antiderivatives, Riemann sums, the definite integral, and the fundamental theorem of calculus.

name: Calculus II
description: Integration techniques, applications of the definite integral, first-order differential equations, vectors and vector operations, parametric equations and polar coordinates, infinite series.

name: Applied Statistics I
description: Introduction to probability, random variables and their expectations, some commonly used discrete and continuous distributions, concept of random sampling and sampling distributions. Use of computer software packages for simulating, summarizing, and displaying data.

name: Elementary Linear Algebra
description: Matrices and their operations, linear systems of equations, Gaussian elimination, determinants, geometry of Euclidean space, vector spaces and subspaces, linear independence, basis, dimension and rank, orthogonality and the Gram-Schmidt process, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, and diagonalization.

name: Academic Writing and Reading
description: Introduces students to principles of effective written communication and critical reading. Stresses invention, drafting, revising, editing, and self-assessment, along with effective critiquing and collaborating. Students may use any of the following courses to satisfy the requirements of the Core, but only one may count: ENG 1100, ENG 1110, ENG 1130, or ENG 1140.

name: Technical Communications for Engineers and Computer Scientists
description: A modular approach to oral and written communication of complex technical information to an expert audience. Includes describing technical mechanisms and processes; designing and using tables, graphs, charts, and figures; producing technical proposals, progress reports, feasibility reports, and formal reports; and doing technical briefings.

name: Team Projects I
description: A summative computer engineering team design project building upon previous engineering, science, mathematics, and communication course work focusing on professional practice in computer science and engineering. Must enroll in CEG 4981 in the following term.

name: Team Projects II
description: CEG 4981 is a continuation of CEG 4980 and must be taken in the term immediately following CEG 4980. Project groups maintain their composition and project from CEG 4980.

name: Differential Equations with Matrix Algebra
description: Introduction to differential equations with matrix theory. Matrices, determinants, vector spaces, least squares solutions, eigenvalues/eigenvectors, matrix diagonalization; first order differential equations, second and higher order linear equations, forced oscillations, systems of linear differential equations, phase plane, and Laplace transforms.

name: Digital System Design
description: Basics of digital computer hardware and design. Topics include switching algebra and switching functions, logic design of combinational and sequential circuits, storage elements, register-level design, and instrumentation.

name: Microprocessor-Based Embedded Systems
description: Introduction to small, special-purpose microprocessor systems. Topics include hardware design issues, software design and implementation, and real-time operating systems.

name: Microprocessor-Based Embedded Systems Lab
description: Required laboratory for CEG 4330.

name: General Physics I
description: Introductory survey of mechanics for science and engineering students. Uses of interpreting physical phenomena. Topics include vectors, kinematics, dynamics, energy, momentum, rotation, oscillation and thermodynamics.

name: General Physics I Lab
description: Introductory physics laboratory problems in mechanics, oscillation and thermodynamics.

name: General Physics II
description: Introductory survey of electricity and magnetism. Uses calculus in interpreting physical phenomena. Topics include electric field and potential, currents, DC circuits, magnetic fields, Faraday's law, and optics.

name: General Physics II Lab
description: Introductory physics laboratory problems in electricity, magnetism, and optics.

name: Circuit Analysis I
description: Basic elements and laws, circuit analysis techniques and concepts, energy storage elements, first and second order circuits, sinusoidal steady state analysis.

name: Circuit Analysis I Lab
description: Computer-assisted analysis, RLC circuits, operational amplifiers and circuits, Thevenin and Norton equivalents, maximum power transfer, and AC networks.

name: Linear Systems I
description: Continuous-time signals and systems, time domain analysis, Laplace transform, Fourier series, Fourier transform, Bode analysis. Various approaches to system and signal modeling.

name: Electronic Devices and Circuits
description: Introduction to basic solid-state electronic devices for discrete and integrated circuits. Major topics include carrier flow in semi-conductors, p-n junction theory, semiconductor diodes, bipolar junction transistors, field effect transistors, biasing, introduction to amplifiers, and frequency response.

name: Electronic Devices and Circuits Lab
description: Laboratory supporting EE 3310 Electronic Devices and Circuits.
